bestBHT.bht: Did I not see thee with my own eyes? This staggering and sudden question, asked with bitterness, aimed to expose Peter's previous denials. Hoping to divert suspicion, Peter had joined in the fireside talk, but this only revealed his connection to Jesus. I saw thee with my own eyes along with Jesus, this very night in the garden, how canst thou deny it? The danger of arrest for his attempt to kill and his desperate desire to distance himself from Jesus drove Peter to vehemently deny his association.

Henry Alford: The 'I' is emphatic in the original: as we say, Did I not see thee with my own eyes?
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Thou art a Galilean, and thy speech agreeth thereto" (Matthew 26:73).
If Peter had held his peace, this peculiarity had not been observed; but hoping, probably, to put them off the scent by joining in the fireside talk, he only thus revealed himself.
Philip Schaff: The circumstance is not merely historical, but that it aids in developing the idea which the Evangelist has in view.
This man would ask his question with far more bitterness than the others.
His question too is much more pointed, not whether Peter is one of the disciples, but whether his own eyes had not seen him but a little before upon a spot which he could name.
Archibald T. Robertson: This staggering and sudden thrust expects an affirmative answer by the use of ουκ, not μη.
Peter's previous denials with the knowledge that he was observed by a kinsman of Malchus whom he had tried to kill drove him to the third flat denial that he knew Jesus.
Peter was in dire peril now of arrest himself for attempt to kill.
John Gill: Hearing him so stiffly deny that he was a disciple of Jesus, when he had great reason to believe he was.
I saw thee with my own eyes along with Jesus, this very night in the garden, how canst thou deny it?
And wilt thou stand in it so confidently, that thou art not one of his disciples?

bhtAttempts.bht: Did I not see thee with my own eyes? This staggering and sudden question, asked with bitterness, aimed to expose Peter's previous denials. Hoping to divert suspicion, Peter had joined in the fireside talk, but this only revealed his connection to Jesus. The kinsman of Malchus, whom Peter had tried to kill, observed him and now pressed him further. I saw thee with my own eyes along with Jesus, this very night in the garden, how canst thou deny it? The danger of arrest for his attempt to kill and his desperate desire to distance himself from Jesus drove Peter to vehemently deny his association with Him, endangering himself even more.
